text: New York's 17th congressional district is a congressional district in the U.S. state of New York. == Presidential election results == Year Office Results 1992 President Clinton 75 - 19% (Bush) 1996 President Clinton 85 - 11% (Dole) 2000 President Gore 69 - 27% (W. Bush) 2004 President Kerry 67 - 33% (W. Bush) 2008 President Obama 72 - 28% (McCain) 2012 President Obama 57 - 41% (Romney) 2016 President H. Clinton 52 - 39% (Trump) 2020 President Biden 60 - 39% (Trump) == List of representatives == === 1803–1833: One seat === Representative Party Years Cong ress Electoral history Location District created March 4, 1803 Oliver Phelps Democratic-Republican March 4, 1803 – March 3, 1805 Elected in 1802. 1803–1813 Silas Halsey Democratic-Republican March 4, 1805 – March 3, 1807 Elected in 1804. Lost re-election. John Harris Democratic-Republican March 4, 1807 – March 3, 1809 Elected in 1806. Lost re-election. District not in use March 4, 1809 – March 3, 1813 William S. Smith Federalist March 4, 1813 – March 3, 1815 Elected in 1812. Re-elected in 1814 but did not take or claim the seat. 1813–1823 Herkimer County, except the Town of Danube; and Madison County. Vacant March 4, 1815 – December 13, 1815 Westel Willoughby Jr. Democratic-Republican December 13, 1815 – March 3, 1817 Successfully contested Smith's election. Thomas H. Hubbard Democratic-Republican March 4, 1817 – March 3, 1819 Elected in 1816. Aaron Hackley Jr. Democratic-Republican March 4, 1819 – March 3, 1821 Elected in 1818. Vacant March 4, 1821 – December 3, 1821 Elections were held in April 1821. It is unclear when results were announced or credentials issued. Thomas H. Hubbard Democratic-Republican December 3, 1821 – March 3, 1823 Elected in 1821. John W. Taylor Democratic-Republican March 4, 1823 – March 3, 1825 Redistricted from 11th district and re-elected in 1822. Re-elected in 1824. Re-elected in 1826. Re-elected in 1828. Re-elected in 1830. Lost re-election. Saratoga County Anti-Jacksonian March 4, 1825 – March 3, 1833 === 1833–1843: Two seats === From 1833 to 1843, two seats were apportioned to the 17th district, elected at-large on a general ticket. ==== Seat A ==== Representative Party Years Cong ress Electoral history Samuel Beardsley Jacksonian March 4, 1833 – March 29, 1836 Redistricted from 14th district and re-elected in 1832. Re-elected in 1834. Resigned to become circuit judge. Vacant March 29, 1836 – November 9, 1836 Rutger B. Miller Jacksonian November 9, 1836 – March 3, 1837 Elected to finish Beardsley's term. Henry A. Foster Democratic March 4, 1837 – March 3, 1839 Elected in 1836. David P. Brewster Democratic March 4, 1839 – March 3, 1843 Elected in 1838. Re-elected in 1840. ==== Seat B ==== Representative Party Years Cong ress Electoral history Joel Turrill Jacksonian March 4, 1833 – March 3, 1837 Elected in 1832. Re-elected in 1834. Abraham P. Grant Democratic March 4, 1837 – March 3, 1839 Elected in 1836. John G. Floyd Democratic March 4, 1839 – March 3, 1843 Elected in 1838. Re-elected in 1840. === 1843–present: One seat === Representative Party Years Cong ress Electoral history Charles S. Benton Democratic March 4, 1843 – March 3, 1847 Elected in 1842. Re-elected in 1844. George Petrie Independent Democrat March 4, 1847 – March 3, 1849 Elected in 1846. Henry P. Alexander Whig March 4, 1849 – March 3, 1851 Elected in 1848. Alexander H. Buell Democratic March 4, 1851 – January 29, 1853 Elected in 1850. Died. Vacant January 29, 1853 – March 3, 1853 Bishop Perkins Democratic March 4, 1853 – March 3, 1855 Elected in 1852. Francis E. Spinner Democratic March 4, 1855 – March 3, 1857 Elected in 1854. Re-elected in 1856. Re-elected in 1858. Republican March 4, 1857 – March 3, 1861 Socrates N. Sherman Republican March 4, 1861 – March 3, 1863 Elected in 1860. Calvin T. Hulburd Republican March 4, 1863 – March 3, 1869 Elected in 1862. Re-elected in 1864. Re-elected in 1866. William A. Wheeler Republican March 4, 1869 – March 3, 1873 Elected in 1868. Re-elected in 1870. Redistricted to 18th district. Robert S. Hale Republican March 4, 1873 – March 3, 1875 Elected in 1872. Martin I. Townsend Republican March 4, 1875 – March 3, 1879 Elected in 1874. Re-elected in 1876. Walter A. Wood Republican March 4, 1879 – March 3, 1883 Elected in 1878. Re-elected in 1880. Henry G. Burleigh Republican March 4, 1883 – March 3, 1885 Elected in 1882. Redistricted to 18th district James G. Lindsley Republican March 4, 1885 – March 3, 1887 Elected in 1884. Stephen T. Hopkins Republican March 4, 1887 – March 3, 1889 Elected in 1886. Charles J. Knapp Republican March 4, 1889 – March 3, 1891 Elected in 1888. Isaac N. Cox Democratic March 4, 1891 – March 3, 1893 Elected in 1890. Francis Marvin Republican March 4, 1893 – March 3, 1895 Elected in 1892. Benjamin B. Odell Jr. Republican March 4, 1895 – March 3, 1899 Elected in 1894. Re-elected in 1896. Arthur S. Tompkins Republican March 4, 1899 – March 3, 1903 Elected in 1898. Re-elected in 1900. Francis E. Shober Democratic March 4, 1903 – March 3, 1905 Elected in 1902. William S. Bennet Republican March 4, 1905 – March 3, 1911 Elected in 1904. Re-elected in 1906. Re-elected in 1908. Henry George Jr. Democratic March 4, 1911 – March 3, 1913 Elected in 1910. Redistricted to 21st district John F. Carew Democratic March 4, 1913 – March 3, 1919 Elected in 1912. Re-elected in 1914. Re-elected in 1916 Redistricted to 18th district Herbert Pell Democratic March 4, 1919 – March 3, 1921 Elected in 1918. Ogden L. Mills Republican March 4, 1921 – March 3, 1927 Elected in 1920. Re-elected in 1922. Re-elected in 1924. William W. Cohen Democratic March 4, 1927 – March 3, 1929 Elected in 1926. Ruth B. Pratt Republican March 4, 1929 – March 3, 1933 Elected in 1928. Re-elected in 1930. Theodore A. Peyser Democratic March 4, 1933 – August 8, 1937 Elected in 1932. Re-elected in 1934. Re-elected in 1936. Died. Vacant August 8, 1937 – November 2, 1937 Bruce F. Barton Republican November 2, 1937 – January 3, 1941 Elected to finish Peyser's term. Re-elected in 1938. Kenneth F. Simpson Republican January 3, 1941 – January 25, 1941 Elected in 1940. Died. Vacant January 29, 1941 – March 11, 1941 Joseph C. Baldwin Republican March 11, 1941 – January 3, 1947 Elected to finish Simpson's term. Re-elected in 1942. Re-elected in 1944. Frederic R. Coudert Jr. Republican January 3, 1947 – January 3, 1959 Elected in 1946. Re-elected in 1948. Re-elected in 1950. Re-elected in 1952. Re-elected in 1954. Re-elected in 1956. John V. Lindsay Republican January 3, 1959 – December 31, 1965 Elected in 1958. Re-elected in 1960. Re-elected in 1962. Re-elected in 1964. Resigned after being elected as Mayor of New York City. Vacant January 1, 1966 – February 7, 1966 Theodore R. Kupferman Republican February 8, 1966 – January 3, 1969 Elected to finish Lindsay's term. Re-elected in 1966. Ed Koch Democratic January 3, 1969 – January 3, 1973 Elected in 1968. Re-elected in 1970. Redistricted to 18th district John M. Murphy Democratic January 3, 1973 – January 3, 1981 Redistricted from 16th district and re-elected in 1972. Re-elected in 1974. Re-elected in 1976. Re-elected in 1978. Guy Molinari Republican January 3, 1981 – January 3, 1983 Elected in 1980. Redistricted to 14th district Ted Weiss Democratic January 3, 1983 – September 14, 1992 Redistricted from 20th district and re-elected in 1982. Re-elected in 1984. Re-elected in 1986. Re-elected in 1988. Re-elected in 1990. Died. Vacant September 15, 1992 – November 2, 1992 Jerry Nadler Democratic November 3, 1992 – January 3, 1993 Elected to finish Weiss's term. Redistricted to 8th district Eliot Engel Democratic January 3, 1993 – January 3, 2013 Redistricted from the and re-elected in 1992. Re-elected in 1994. Re-elected in 1996. Re-elected in 1998. Re-elected in 2000. Re-elected in 2002. Re-elected in 2004. Re-elected in 2006. Re-elected in 2008. Re-elected in 2010. Redistricted to the . Nita Lowey Democratic January 3, 2013 – January 3, 2021 Redistricted from the and re-elected in 2012. Re-elected in 2014. Re-elected in 2016. Re-elected in 2018. Retired. Mondaire Jones Democratic January 3, 2021 – Present Elected in 2020. == References == 17
title: New York's 17th congressional district
